Name: Tebuconazole
Description: 1-(4-chlorophenyl)-4,4-dimethyl-3-(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)pentan-3-ol is a tertiary alcohol that is pentan-3-ol substituted by a 4-chlorophenyl, methyl, methyl, and a 1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl at positions 1, 4, 4 and 3 respectively. It is a member of monochlorobenzenes, a member of triazoles and a tertiary alcohol.

plant_translocations.content: The study specifically examined the behavior of tebuconazole, finding it is readily taken up by Phragmites roots through passive transport alongside transpirational water flow. Interestingly, tebuconazole is then effectively translocated throughout the plant via the vascular system, becoming concentrated in shoots and leaves. More notably, the research demonstrates tebuconazole degradation occurs endogenously within plant tissues. Through metabolic reactions, the plant works to break down tebuconazole residues inside both roots and aerial portions. Most importantly, this breakdown shows enantioselective tendencies, proceeding at different rates for each tebuconazole enantiomer. This ability of wetland plants like Phragmites to actively uptake, translocate and metabolize applied pesticides like tebuconazole through intrinsic biochemical processes has important implications. It suggests these systems may play an active role in phytoremediation of contaminated sites beyond merely sequestering compounds. Their metabolic capabilities could aid in natural biodegradation and removal of agrochemicals from the environment over time.
plant_translocations.reference: Lv, T., Carvalho, P. N., Casas, M. E., Bollmann, U. E., Arias, C. A., Brix, H., & Bester, K. (2017). Enantioselective uptake, translocation and degradation of the chiral pesticides tebuconazole and imazalil by  Phragmites australis. Environmental Pollution, 229, 362–370. doi:10.1016/j.envpol.2017.06.017

method.Plant Grown Condition: Similar size (6.0 ± 0.2 g fresh biomass), The plants were placed in 700 mL glass vessels with their stems mounted in the lids of these glass vessels using soft polyethylene foam while ensuring that all roots were submerged in 500 mL of hydroponic solution。
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: Tebuconazole (n = 27), Imazalil (n = 27), Solution control (spiked with 10 mg/L tebuconazole and 10 mg/L imazalil, n = 9), Plant control (plants in solution without pesticides, n = 6). Sampling of the solutions and plants were carried out on days 0, 0.5, 1, 2, 5, 10, 15, 20 and 24 after spiking the vessels with the respective pesticides.

plant_translocations.content: Brown root rot disease (BRRD), caused by Phellinus noxius, is a significant tree disease in tropical and subtropical regions. To enhance the chemical control of BRRD and prevent the emergence of fungicide resistance in P. noxius, this study examined the control efficacy and systemic activity of fungicides with various modes of action. Fourteen fungicides with different modes of action were tested for their inhibitory effects on 39 P. noxius isolates from multiple regions. Cyproconazole, epoxiconazole, and tebuconazole (target-site G1) exhibited colony growth inhibition of P. noxius by 99.9% to 100% at 10 ppm and 97.7% to 99.8% at 1 ppm. Another effective fungicide was cyprodinil + fludioxonil (target-site D1 + E2), which showed growth inhibition of 96.9% at 10 ppm and 88.6% at 1 ppm. Acropetal translocation of six selected fungicides was evaluated in bishop wood (Bischofia javanica) seedlings, with cyproconazole and tebuconazole being the most efficiently absorbed by roots and transported acropetally. Greenhouse experiments indicated that cyproconazole, tebuconazole, and epoxiconazole have slightly higher potential for controlling BRRD compared to mepronil, prochloraz, and cyprodinil + fludioxonil. Since all tested fungicides lacked basipetal translocation, soil drenching should be considered over trunk injection for their use in BRRD control.
plant_translocations.reference: Liao, T. Z., Chen, Y. H., Tsai, J. N., Chao, C., Huang, T. P., Hong, C. F., ... & Chung, C. L. (2023). Translocation of fungicides and their efficacy in controlling Phellinus noxius, the cause of brown root rot disease. Plant Disease, 107(7), 2039-2053.

method.Test Plant: Bischofia javanica (bishop wood seedlings), 6-12 months old used due to abundant roots, tender tissues, high susceptibility
method.Plant Grown Condition: Maintained at 35°C day/30°C night, 55-95% RH in phytotron. Under natural light. Leaves trimmed to 3-5 trifoliate leaves per plant before assays
method.Chemical Preparation: Root immersion - 100 ppm solutions of fungicides. Stem injection - Stock solutions ranging 75,000-625,000 ppm injected at 3 μL
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: Acropetal - 5 root tips immersed in 50 mL fungicide solution. Bidirectional - 3 μL fungicide stock injected into stem
method.Other Information: Sampling at 7 and 21 days after treatment. Plant dissected into 5 cm segments (roots, stems, leaves). Fungicide concentrations measured by LC/GC-MS/MS. 2 independent trials with 6 plants per treatment (3 per timepoint)

plant_translocations.content: The study investigated the uptake and distribution of fungicides fluopyram and tebuconazole in tomato and bell pepper plants following soil drench application of their combination product fluopyram 17.7% + tebuconazole 17.7%. The QuEChERS method with LC-MS/MS was used for extraction and cleanup of samples, with LOD and LOQ of 1.5 μgkg−1 and 0.005 mg kg−1, respectively. Rapid uptake of the fungicides by both plants was observed from the first day, with major accumulation in tomato roots and in both bell pepper roots and leaves. Residue accumulation in fruits was lowest and well below MRLs, with maximum concentrations in tomato fruits of 0.060 mg kg−1 for fluopyram and 0.009 mg kg−1 for tebuconazole, and in bell pepper fruits of 0.080 mg kg−1 for fluopyram and 0.013 mg kg−1 for tebuconazole. In field soil, initial fluopyram residues were 3.18–3.570 mg kg−1 and dissipated with a half-life of 36 days, while tebuconazole concentrations were 1.57–1.892 mg kg−1 initially and dissipated with a half-life of 44.5–49.5 days. The major metabolite, fluopyram benzamide, was detected in plant tissues and soil, remaining within 12% of the parent compound. These results suggest that the entry of fluopyram and tebuconazole into the food chain through tomato and bell pepper fruits is unlikely if grown in soil contaminated with these fungicides.
plant_translocations.reference: Matadha, N. Y., Mohapatra, S., Siddamallaiah, L., Udupi, V. R., Gadigeppa, S., & Raja, D. P. (2019). Uptake and distribution of fluopyram and tebuconazole residues in tomato and bell pepper plant tissues. Environmental Science and Pollution Research, 26, 6077-6086.

method.Apply Location: soil drench at a rate of 0.5 mL/L of water at the fruiting stage.
method.Plant Grown Condition: The plants were grown in sandy loam soil (Typic Haplustalf) with a pH of 6.6 and organic carbon content of 0.4%. They were maintained in an experimental field at the Indian Institute of Horticulture Research, Bengaluru (latitude 13.13°N, longitude 77.49°E), from October 2017 to January 2018.
method.Chemical Preparation: Certified reference materials of fluopyram (purity 99.4%), fluopyram benzamide (purity 99.4%), and tebuconazole (purity 96.6%) were used. LCMS/MS-grade acetonitrile, methanol, acetic acid, ammonium formate, and formic acid were also used.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: The formulated product was applied as a soil drench at the fruiting stage. The tomato and bell pepper plants were chosen for the study in a randomized block design with a plot size of 5m × 5m, and a plant-to-plant distance of 60 cm was maintained.
method.Other Information: The field study was conducted with three replications of treatments.

plant_translocations.content: The study focused on the uptake, translocation, and subcellular distribution of three triazole pesticides (triadimefon, tebuconazole, and epoxiconazole) in rice plants, which are commonly used to control pathogenic fungi in crops but have raised concerns about food safety due to their residues in edible crops. The results showed that all three pesticides could be taken up by rice roots, with varying distribution patterns in plant tissues. Epoxiconazole exhibited the highest accumulation in rice roots, followed by tebuconazole and then triadimefon, while the reverse order was observed in rice shoots. The movement of these pesticides within rice tissues involved both symplast and apoplast pathways, with different preferences for each pesticide. Subcellular distribution analysis revealed that all three pesticides had a higher proportion in cell walls compared to cell organelles and soluble components. Epoxiconazole had the highest accumulation in cell walls, while triadimefon was more concentrated in soluble components. The study concluded that the uptake, movement, and subcellular distribution of these pesticides are influenced by their hydrophobicity, highlighting the complex interactions between pesticides and plant tissues.
plant_translocations.reference: Li, H., Li, Y., Wang, W., Wan, Q., Yu, X., & Sun, W. (2022). Uptake, translocation, and subcellular distribution of three triazole pesticides in rice. Environmental Science and Pollution Research, 1-10.

method.Test Plant: Rice (Oryza sativa L. japonica cv. Nipponbare)
method.Plant Grown Condition: Rice seeds were surface-disinfected, germinated on wet filter paper at 30°C, then transplanted to black plastic hydroponic containers (9x13x12 cm) and grown under controlled conditions (130±5 μmol/m2s light, 16h light/8h dark, 60% RH, 32/25°C day/night temp). Healthy 3-leaf stage seedlings were selected for exposure tests.
method.Chemical Preparation: Pesticide standards of triadimefon, tebuconazole and epoxiconazole (>99% purity) were used. Nutrient solution was spiked with 1 mg/L of each pesticide separately for exposure.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: Rice seedlings were exposed to 1 mg/L of triadimefon, tebuconazole or epoxiconazole by spiking the pesticide into the hydroponic nutrient solution.
method.Other Information: Experiments were conducted in triplicate. At 0, 3, 6, 12, 24 and 48 h, 9 rice plants and nutrient solution samples were collected from each replicate for residue analysis.

plant_translocations.content: The study examined the translocation and degradation kinetics of prothioconazole and tebuconazole, two fungicides effective against Fusarium head blight (FHB) in wheat. In greenhouse experiments, minimal translocation of the fungicides (<1%) was observed from flag leaves to ears and a maximum of 3.55% from ears to flag leaves. Field experiments showed that degradation kinetics were faster in flag leaf blades than in ears, with varying rates depending on cultivar. Despite differences in degradation rates, both fungicides resulted in significant decreases (42.6–100%) in FHB traits. The findings suggest that while there is limited translocation of these fungicides, moderate redistribution in the ears occurs, which can be crucial for FHB management. Cultivar and environmental factors also influenced degradation kinetics, but overall, effective protection against FHB was maintained.
plant_translocations.reference: Lehoczki‐Krsjak, S., Varga, M., Szabó‐Hevér, Á., & Mesterházy, Á. (2013). Translocation and degradation of tebuconazole and prothioconazole in wheat following fungicide treatment at flowering. Pest management science, 69(11), 1216-1224.

method.Test Plant: Three wheat cultivars differing in Fusarium resistance were used - GK Békes (susceptible to FHB with awns), GK Kalász (susceptible, awnless) and GK Fény (moderately resistant to FHB, awnless).
method.Apply Location: Foliar application (ears, flag leaves and spikelets were treated)
method.Plant Grown Condition: Wheat seedlings were grown in plastic tubes containing 1:1 peat and sandy soil mix. After vernalization, plants were grown in PVC containers with 1:1 peat and sandy soil mix in a semi-automatic greenhouse under 16h photoperiod at 25-32°C day and 15-19°C night temperature. Plants were fertilized 3 times with Volldünger fertilizer.
method.Chemical Preparation: A triazole fungicide mixture containing 125g/L prothioconazole and 125g/L tebuconazole (Prosaro from Bayer CropScience) was diluted in distilled water to be equivalent to 1L Prosaro in 250L solution.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: The fungicide mixture was applied by brushing at mid-flowering stage (GS65) to complete ears, flag leaf blades and outer spikelets on same side of ears separately to study basipetal and acropetal translocation.
method.Other Information: Field trials were conducted in 2010 and 2011 in Szeged, Hungary with the same 3 wheat cultivars sown at 550 seeds/m2 in 5.2m2 plots with 3 replicates per treatment in randomized design
